Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Rubber Particle Dissection and Directed Reconstitution in Synthetic Vesicles
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I proposes to develop a foundation for the production of rubber and high-value elastomers through the identification of the members of the elusive rubber transferase complex. The proposed novel research utilizes recently-developed biochemical separation protocols to concentrate membrane-bound rubber transferases several hundred-fold while simultaneously removing the rubber phase. Phase I of the project will focus on utilizing this technique to achieve the following specific aims: isolation of intact membrane-bound rubber transferase complexes from rubber particle membranes; characterization of bioactive lipids in rubber particle membranes; identification of rubber transferase proteins through a combination of proteomic and transcriptomic analysis; and expression of rubber transferase peptides in optimized heterologous systems. Data generated by this research will allow, for the first time, the purification and identification of members of the rubber transferase complex from membranes enriched in these proteins. Heterologous expression of these proteins paves the way for the construction of synthetic rubber production systems, and improvement of on-farm rubber crops.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project, if successful, is to enable the development of commercial rubber crops cultivated in the US. Over 93% of global natural rubber production is in Asia and relies on a single clonally-produced crop species (Hevea brasiliensis). The severe geographic restrictions for this crop are a major factor limiting natural rubber production. Current market models predict that, by the end of this decade, the world may experience a cumulative rubber shortfall of 6.6 million metric tons (US consumption is 1.2 MT/yr). This shortfall will have a dramatic negative impact on agricultural, civil, and military economic sectors. Rubber-producing plant species suitable for the US have been identified and are the focus of intensive commercial development and scientific research. This project will significantly increase the scientific understanding of rubber biosynthesis and speed the development and deployment of millions of acres of high yielding alternative rubber crops. It will enable the application of both molecular assisted breeding and biotechnological approaches to crop improvement and help create opportunities to introduce rubber production as a co-product of established crops. New rubber crops will create at least 5,000 new agribusiness jobs for every 50,000 acres, and self-sufficiency will require 2-4 million acres.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Natural rubber is a strategically essential raw material for the United States, which imports nearly 1.7 million metric tons of this material per year. Most natural rubber imported into the US is produced by the tropically-grown para rubber tree (Hevea brasiliensis). Unfortunately, increased global demand, particularly from the emerging Asian economies of India, China and Brazil, are causing global shortfalls and dramatic volatility in natural rubber prices. Natural rubber shortfalls and price increases can have a dramatic impact on the national economy, as this material is an irreplaceable component of the automotive, medical, aerospace, and defense industries. While the biochemistry of rubber synthesis has been well-defined, the molecular mechanisms underlying this process are still unclear. Further, despite the work of many researchers, the enzymes responsible for rubber synthesis have not been definitively identified, nor have the rubber polymerase genes been cloned. Identification of these enzymes and cloning of these genes would greatly facilitate biotechnology-based approaches to rubber crop improvement and allow the design and implementation of new rubber production systems.

Research conducted under this NSF STTR Phase I project (Project no. 1346397: “Rubber particle dissection and directed reconstitution in synthetic vesicles”) was focused on identifying the proteins involved in rubber synthesis and generating data allowing these proteins to be employed in the creation of alternate plant- and microbe-based rubber production systems. Preliminary data generated by our group indicated that the elusive “rubber polymerase” (the enzyme responsible for rubber production) was actually most likely a “rubber synthetase complex”, i.e., a complex made up of multiple proteins and enzymes functioning together to generate rubber molecules. Further, our preliminary studies indicated that this rubber synthetase complex was likely located in the membrane enclosing and defining the rubber particle (the subcellular compartment in which rubber synthesis occurs). Throughout the course of the project, we have used a novel approach combining both broad-scale gene and protein sequencing and identification with cutting-edge protein expression systems to: a. identify members of the rubber synthetase complex; and b. express these proteins in plant, microbial, and non-plant synthetic systems. The research accomplished throughout this NSF Phase I STTR project has intellectual merit in that it has “advanced the frontiers of knowledge” by beginning to define the basic mechanisms involved in rubber synthesis. Data gained throughout the course of the project will allow the re-constitution of the individual members of the rubber synthetase complex into a fully functioning unit (capable of generating rubber) in synthetic membrane vesicles, microbial systems, or genetically engineered plant systems. The broader impact of the research is that it lays the foundation for the generation of a multitude of commercially viable, environmentally-sustainable rubber crops, as well as bio-reactors for the production of unique, high-value, elastomers. Specific milestones achieved during the lifetime of the project are described below:

 

1. Isolate and purify the membrane enclosing and defining the rubber particle: Throughout the course of the project, we have developed and refined methods to purify membranes and membrane sub-domains from rubber particles extracted from guayule (Parthenium argentatum), a rubber producing woody species native to North America. Isolation of these membranes allowed us to concentrate p...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Natural rubber is a strategically essential raw material for the United States, which imports nearly 1.7 million metric tons of this material per year. Most natural rubber imported into the US is produced by the tropically-grown para rubber tree (Hevea brasiliensis). Unfortunately, increased global demand, particularly from the emerging Asian economies of India, China and Brazil, are causing global shortfalls and dramatic volatility in natural rubber prices. Natural rubber shortfalls and price increases can have a dramatic impact on the national economy, as this material is an irreplaceable component of the automotive, medical, aerospace, and defense industries. While the biochemistry of rubber synthesis has been well-defined, the molecular mechanisms underlying this process are still unclear. Further, despite the work of many researchers, the enzymes responsible for rubber synthesis have not been definitively identified, nor have the rubber polymerase genes been cloned. Identification of these enzymes and cloning of these genes would greatly facilitate biotechnology-based approaches to rubber crop improvement and allow the design and implementation of new rubber production systems. Research conducted under this NSF STTR Phase I project (Project no. 1346397: "Rubber particle dissection and directed reconstitution in synthetic vesicles") was focused on identifying the proteins involved in rubber synthesis and generating data allowing these proteins to be employed in the creation of alternate plant- and microbe-based rubber production systems. Preliminary data generated by our group indicated that the elusive "rubber polymerase" (the enzyme responsible for rubber production) was actually most likely a "rubber synthetase complex", i.e., a complex made up of multiple proteins and enzymes functioning together to generate rubber molecules. Further, our preliminary studies indicated that this rubber synthetase complex was likely located in the membrane enclosing and defining the rubber particle (the subcellular compartment in which rubber synthesis occurs). Throughout the course of the project, we have used a novel approach combining both broad-scale gene and protein sequencing and identification with cutting-edge protein expression systems to: a. identify members of the rubber synthetase complex; and b. express these proteins in plant, microbial, and non-plant synthetic systems. The research accomplished throughout this NSF Phase I STTR project has intellectual merit in that it has "advanced the frontiers of knowledge" by beginning to define the basic mechanisms involved in rubber synthesis. Data gained throughout the course of the project will allow the re-constitution of the individual members of the rubber synthetase complex into a fully functioning unit (capable of generating rubber) in synthetic membrane vesicles, microbial systems, or genetically engineered plant systems. The broader impact of the research is that it lays the foundation for the generation of a multitude of commercially viable, environmentally-sustainable rubber crops, as well as bio-reactors for the production of unique, high-value, elastomers. Specific milestones achieved during the lifetime of the project are described below: 1. Isolate and purify the membrane enclosing and defining the rubber particle: Throughout the course of the project, we have developed and refined methods to purify membranes and membrane sub-domains from rubber particles extracted from guayule (Parthenium argentatum), a rubber producing woody species native to North America. Isolation of these membranes allowed us to concentrate proteins embedded in the membrane several hundred-fold, facilitating completion of milestones 2 and 3 (below). 2. Define the composition of the rubber particle membrane: A range of analytical biochemical techniques were used to separate and identify components of the rubber particle membrane.
